elements.content: Five novel three-dimensional lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln–MOFs) constructed by 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy) phthalic acid (H4dcppa), namely, {[Eu­(Hdcppa)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (Eu-1), [Eu1.5(dcppa) (HCOO)0.5(H2O)2] n (Eu-2), {[Ln2K2(dcppa)2(H2O)6]·mH2O} n (Ln = Eu-3, Tb-4, Gd-5, m = 5 for Eu-3 and Tb-4; m = 4 for Gd-5) (HCOOH = formic acid) have been prepared by hydro­(solvo)­thermal method and fully characterized. Structural analyses indicated that H4dcppa ligand took four different coordination fashions in 1–5 and, thus, resulted in diversity of the targeted Ln–MOFs: Eu-1 displays the rare 3D (5,5)-connected vbk net, containing one-dimensional left- and right-handed helical chains; Eu-2 possesses a 3D (3,8)-connected tfz-d topology constructed by trinuclear paddlewheel [Eu3(CO2)6] SBUs; 3–5 are isostructural and show 3D (Ln-dcppa4–) + 2D (K-dcppa4–) → 3D (LnK-dcppa4–) structure. Eu-3, with regular 1D channels and open Lewis basic oxygen atoms on the pore surface was utilized for specific sensing and binding of metal ions through Lewis base interactions, shows high selectivity, fast response time (8 min), and high sensitivity (K SV = 4.3/5.2 × 104 L/mol) for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions with luminescent quenching. Furthermore, the detection limit of the sensor is in the 10–6 M level. The triplet state (T1 = 23364 cm–1) of H4dcppa studied by the Gd­(III)–MOF and Gd-5 demonstrates that the ligand ideally populates Eu­(III)/Tb­(III) emission with luminescent quantum yields (Φoverall) of 11.2% for Eu-1, 27.6% for Eu-2, 18.5% for Eu-3, and 62% for Tb-4, respectively.

Furthermore, the detection limit of the sensor is in the 10-6 M level. The triplet state (T1 = 23364 cm-1) of H4dcppa studied by the Gd(III)-MOF and Gd-5 demonstrates that the ligand ideally populates Eu(III)/Tb(III) emission with luminescent quantum yields (Φoverall) of 11.2% for Eu-1, 27.6% for Eu-2, 18.5% for Eu-3, and 62% for Tb-4, respectively.

elements.content: Five novel 3D lanthanide metal−organic frameworks constructed by mono-, tri-, and heterometallic tetranuclear clusters. Eu-3 shows highly sensitive and selective luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ion.
elements.clean_text: Five novel 3D lanthanide metal-organic frameworks constructed by mono-, tri-, and heterometallic tetranuclear clusters. Eu-3 shows highly sensitive and selective luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ion.

elements.content: Iron­(III) (Fe3+) is a universal metal in environmental system and especially in the biosphere played a central role. It plays significant part in oxygen metabolism, oxygen uptake, and electron transfer. In addition, copper­(II) (Cu2+) is the second most important and essential ions, after iron, in living biological systems, particularly in terms of photophysical changes of brain, the straightforward, efficient, even the response time of a trace amount of Cu2+ in the biological systems will be helpful to understand the factors for related copper metabolism disordered Wilson’s disease and thus could provide possible methods for its treatment. Luminescent materials of lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln–MOFs) can be acted as bright, promising host matrixes for molecular-ion recognition owing to their designable architectures and tunable chemical and physical properties. In comparison to transition-metal-based MOFs, Ln–MOFs are particularly interesting for this type of application due to the distinct optical property containing high color purity, large Stokes shift value, visible color with the naked eye, and relatively long luminescence lifetimes, which originally come from f–f transitions via an “antenna effect”. Up to now, a number of Ln–MOFs have been successfully applied for the sensing of small molecules (e.g.: TNT and acetone) and ions (for instance Fe3+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Mg2+, Ag+, F–, etc.), which are summarized in . However, the synthesis of Ln–MOFs with fast response time (about 2–24 h in a previous report) and high sensitivity to metal ions is still a challenging and attractive research topic. When the analyte as receptor, a quenching or enhancement fluorescence signals can be observed in the fluorescence maxima due to either energy transfer (ET), charge transfer (CT), or electron transfer (ET) processes. In contrast, detection based on fluorescence quenching has advantages over other detection methods for its simplicity, short response time, high sensibility, visualization, and ability to be applied in both solution and solid phases.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Iron(III) (Fe3+) is a universal metal in environmental system and especially in the biosphere played a central role. It plays significant part in oxygen metabolism, oxygen uptake, and electron transfer. In addition, copper(II) (Cu2+) is the second most important and essential ions, after iron, in living biological systems, particularly in terms of photophysical changes of brain, the straightforward, efficient, even the response time of a trace amount of Cu2+ in the biological systems will be helpful to understand the factors for related copper metabolism disordered Wilson's disease and thus could provide possible methods for its treatment. Luminescent materials of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) can be acted as bright, promising host matrixes for molecular-ion recognition owing to their designable architectures and tunable chemical and physical properties. In comparison to transition-metal-based MOFs, Ln-MOFs are particularly interesting for this type of application due to the distinct optical property containing high color purity, large Stokes shift value, visible color with the naked eye, and relatively long luminescence lifetimes, which originally come from f-f transitions via an "antenna effect". Up to now, a number of Ln-MOFs have been successfully applied for the sensing of small molecules (e.g.: TNT and acetone) and ions (for instance Fe3+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Mg2+, Ag+, F-, etc.), which are summarized in . However, the synthesis of Ln-MOFs with fast response time (about 2-24 h in a previous report) and high sensitivity to metal ions is still a challenging and attractive research topic. When the analyte as receptor, a quenching or enhancement fluorescence signals can be observed in the fluorescence maxima due to either energy transfer (ET), charge transfer (CT), or electron transfer (ET) processes. In contrast, detection based on fluorescence quenching has advantages over other detection methods for its simplicity, short response time, high sensibility, visualization, and ability to be applied in both solution and solid phases.

elements.content: The luminescent porous frameworks with free Lewis acidic/basic sites are recognized as anion/cation receptors, and also can be attractive candidates as luminescent sensor. In porous frameworks, the immobilization of free sites is difficult, because the tendency of frameworks could bond with other metal cations to construct novel frameworks. However, it is very challenging to realize open Lewis basic sites within porous MOFs because such Lewis basic sites are easily occupied by other metal cations to form condensed phases. In fact, some reports focus on transitional metal–organic frameworks, which are constructed by 4-(3′,5′-dicarboxylphenoxy)­phthalic acid (H4dcppa) or other tetracarboxylate acid ligand with diverse kinds of substituent position (summarized in ). As far as we known, Ln–MOFs based on H4dcppa have never been studied in previous literature. From the relevant research literature, we can see that transition metal–organic frameworks containing H4dcppa with various structures and properties could be influenced by ancillary N-donor ligands. In our work, diverse crystal structures of Ln–MOFs could be obtained only based on H4dcppa ligand, owing to the hard–soft acid/base classification. Taking advantage of the excellent sensing properties of Ln–MOFs with the aforementioned ideas in mind, H4dcppa was selected as candidate to construct Ln–MOFs based on the following considerations: (1) it contains four carboxylic substituents, and can be provided with the freely rotating of two phenyl rings bridged by O atom, which benefit to forming permanent porosity and robust frameworks; (2) the high-performance antenna effect originating from the largely electronic conjugate system in H4dcppa can make energy easily transferable to lanthanide luminescent centers. In addition, Eu3+ and Tb3+ cations have pure and sharp red and green emissions arising from characteristic 4f electronic transitions, which can be employed as sensitive optical signal.

In addition, Eu3+ and Tb3+ cations have pure and sharp red and green emissions arising from characteristic 4f electronic transitions, which can be employed as sensitive optical signal.

elements.content: In this work, we demonstrate five novel 3D Ln–MOFs based on asymmetric semirigid ligand by tuning reaction pH values, potassium source, base and solvent, {[Eu­(Hdcppa)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (Eu-1), [Eu1.5(dcppa) (HCOO)0.5(H2O)2] n (Eu-2), {[Ln2K2(dcppa)2(H2O)6]·mH2O} n (Ln = Eu-3, Tb-4, Gd-5, m = 5 for Eu-3 and Tb-4; m = 4 for Gd-5). Eu-1 and Eu-2 display “Chinese knots” and “dragon boats” like 3D networks, respectively. It is worth mentioning that, K+ ion can serve as advantageous components in MOFs assembly due to the low polarizability, various coordinative admissibility, and individual affinity for diverse basic molecules (either strong or weak). The introduction of K+ cation will open a new avenue for changing the size and geometry of heterometallic MOFs. Remarkably, 3–5 are heterometallic s/4f complexes (s–block and 4f ions) when K2C2O4 added in the reaction system and show 3D (Ln–dcppa4–) + 2D (K–dcppa4–) → 3D (LnK–dcppa4–) structure. The luminescent explorations revealed that Eu-3, with 1D channels and open Lewis basic oxygen atoms on the pore surface, belongs to the luminescent probe for Fe3+ and Cu2+ possessing relatively high selectivity, fast response time (8 min), and high sensitivity with K SV = 4.3/5.2 × 104 L/mol (K SV is Stern–Volmer constant) among 15 kinds of metal ions. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties and quantum yields as well as energy transfer process of complexes 1–4 have been studied in details.

elements.content: All reagents (Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O, H4dcppa, KOH, and K2C2O4) and DMF solvent were commercially purchased and used as current state. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets using a Nicolet Avatar 360 infrared spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 240c element analyzer. Perkin–Elmer Lambda 20 spectrometer is used to obtain the solid UV–vis spectra. PANalytical X-ray diffractometer is used to record PXRD patterns. The thermal analysis was recorded on a ZRY–2P thermogravimetric analyzer from 30 to 700 °C with heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under air conditions. The solid state photoluminescent properties were measured on an Edinburgh FLS 920 luminescence spectrometer in 200–800 nm region both at 298 and 77 K. The quantum yields of the complexes (Eu-1, Eu-2, Eu-3, and Tb-4) were determined according to an absolute method of Wrighton using an integrating sphere from Edinburgh Instruments FLS 920. XPS analyses were performed on an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents (Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O, H4dcppa, KOH, and K2C2O4) and DMF solvent were commercially purchased and used as current state. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets using a Nicolet Avatar 360 infrared spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analyses for C, H, N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240c element analyzer. Perkin-Elmer Lambda 20 spectrometer is used to obtain the solid UV-vis spectra. PANalytical X-ray diffractometer is used to record PXRD patterns. The thermal analysis was recorded on a ZRY-2P thermogravimetric analyzer from 30 to 700 °C with heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under air conditions. The solid state photoluminescent properties were measured on an Edinburgh FLS 920 luminescence spectrometer in 200-800 nm region both at 298 and 77 K. The quantum yields of the complexes (Eu-1, Eu-2, Eu-3, and Tb-4) were determined according to an absolute method of Wrighton using an integrating sphere from Edinburgh Instruments FLS 920. XPS analyses were performed on an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.

elements.content: A mixture of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (44.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4dcppa (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (6 mL). The final pH value was adjusted to 4.0 using 0.5 mol·L–1 potassium hydrate. After stirring for half–hour in air, the mixture was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, which was heated to 160 °C for 5 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient condition. Colorless block-shaped crystals of Eu-1 were collected, yield: 31.8 mg, 58% based on H4dcppa. Elemental analysis calcd for [C16H13EuO12 (549.22)]: C, 34.99, H, 2.39%; found: C, 34.93, H, 2.37%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3435 (br), 1700 (s), 1621 (m), 1566 (s), 1519 (m), 1386 (s), 1276 (s), 1215 (m), 1162 (w), 1085 (w), 987 (s), 899 (m), 844 (m), 789 (m), 765 (m), 674 (m), 631 (w), 594 (s), 529 (w), 427 (w).

Luminescence Quenching Experiments

The crystals of {[Eu2K2(dcppa)2(H2O)6]⋅5H2O} n  (Eu-3) were dispersed in the ethanol solutions of MCl x  at room temperature (M = Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Cu+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, respectively) to form metal-Eu-3 complexes (M n+-Eu-3).

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction data taken at room temperature for complexes 1–5 were collected on a Siemens SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite–monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0. 71073 Å). The structures of 1–5 were solved by direct and Fourier methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares using the standard crystallographic software SHELXT-2014 and SHELXL-2014. In Eu-2, the solvent molecules were highly disordered, which have been treated as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom positions by SQUEEZE/PLATON. The SQUEEZE result is appended to CIF file. All ring H atoms, assigned on the basis of geometrical considerations, were all allowed to ride on their respective C atoms. All hydrogen atoms were assigned fixed Uiso values, equal to 1.2 and 1.5 Ueq of the parent atom for ring and water H atoms, respectively. In complexes 2–5, the electron density peaks of various H atoms which bonded to water O atoms were not clear enough. Hence, in the models, the refinements were completed without these water H atoms. shows the crystallographic data and structural refinements of complexes 1–5. CCDC reference numbers: 1481693 for Eu-1, 1481694 for Eu-2, 1481695 for Eu-3, 1481696 for Tb-4, and 1481697 for Gd-5. The important bond lengths and angles of complexes 1–5 are summarized in Tables S3 and S4.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The X-ray diffraction data taken at room temperature for complexes 1-5 were collected on a Siemens SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0. 71073 Å). The structures of 1-5 were solved by direct and Fourier methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares using the standard crystallographic software SHELXT-2014 and SHELXL-2014. In Eu-2, the solvent molecules were highly disordered, which have been treated as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom positions by SQUEEZE/PLATON. The SQUEEZE result is appended to CIF file. All ring H atoms, assigned on the basis of geometrical considerations, were all allowed to ride on their respective C atoms. All hydrogen atoms were assigned fixed Uiso values, equal to 1.2 and 1.5 Ueq of the parent atom for ring and water H atoms, respectively. In complexes 2-5, the electron density peaks of various H atoms which bonded to water O atoms were not clear enough. Hence, in the models, the refinements were completed without these water H atoms.  shows the crystallographic data and structural refinements of complexes 1-5. CCDC reference numbers: 1481693 for Eu-1, 1481694 for Eu-2, 1481695 for Eu-3, 1481696 for Tb-4, and 1481697 for Gd-5. The important bond lengths and angles of complexes 1-5 are summarized in Tables S3 and S4.

In this work, five 3D Ln–MOFs based on asymmetric semirigid H4dcppa ligand have successfully isolated by hydro­(solvo)­thermally methods with KOH as a modulator, the reaction routes of which are shown in . Eu-1 shows a rare (5,5)-connected vbk 3D framework constructed by 1D helix chains. The 5′-position carboxyl group of H4dppca is not deprotonation under pH = 4.0 circumstance. When the pH value ascent to 4.5, “dragon boats” like 3D Eu-2, which features a neutral framework with (3,8)-connected tfz-d topology, was obtained. All the carboxyl groups are completely deprotonated in Eu-2. In fact, the torsion between phenyl rings and carboxyl groups determines the coordination modes and configurations of H4dcppa ligand (). For Eu-1, H4dcppa ligand shows μ5-bridging mode, and 3-, 4-, and 3′-carboxylic groups exhibit μ1–η1:η1, μ2–η1:η1, and μ2–η1:η1 coordination mode, respectively. For Eu-2, H4dcppa ligand shows μ6-bridging mode: 3- and 4-carboxylic groups exhibit μ2–η1:η2 coordination mode, 3′-carboxylic group exhibits μ1–η1:η1 coordination mode, and 5′-position carboxylic group exhibits trans–syn-μ2–η1:η1 coordination mode, respectively. Due to the existence of chelate–monatomic bridge coordination mode, Eu-2 is built based on [Eu3(CO2)6] trinuclear cluster units, while Eu-1 is constructed from helical chains. We ameliorated the synthetic methodology, the pH value continues to improve to 4.9 and add K2C2O4 to the reaction system. Complexes 3–5 are heterometallic s/4f complexes, namely, the Ln3+ ion and the first main group K+ ion are cooperatively performed in the coordination process. Interestingly, Ln3+ ion and K+ ion are interconnected by carboxyl groups to afford two kinds of tetranuclear hetermetallic cluster, which are axial symmetry geometry. It is worth mentioning that, O5 and O13 bridging one lanthanide ion and two K+ ions adopt η3 coordination mode. This is significantly different from Eu-1 and Eu-2. The discovery of hetermetallic clusters help to expand hetermetallic clusters in Ln–MOFs system.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

In this work, five 3D Ln-MOFs based on asymmetric semirigid H4dcppa ligand have successfully isolated by hydro(solvo)thermally methods with KOH as a modulator, the reaction routes of which are shown in . Eu-1 shows a rare (5,5)-connected vbk 3D framework constructed by 1D helix chains. The 5'-position carboxyl group of H4dppca is not deprotonation under pH = 4.0 circumstance. When the pH value ascent to 4.5, "dragon boats" like 3D Eu-2, which features a neutral framework with (3,8)-connected tfz-d topology, was obtained. All the carboxyl groups are completely deprotonated in Eu-2. In fact, the torsion between phenyl rings and carboxyl groups determines the coordination modes and configurations of H4dcppa ligand (). For Eu-1, H4dcppa ligand shows μ5-bridging mode, and 3-, 4-, and 3'-carboxylic groups exhibit μ1-η1:η1, μ2-η1:η1, and μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode, respectively. For Eu-2, H4dcppa ligand shows μ6-bridging mode: 3- and 4-carboxylic groups exhibit μ2-η1:η2 coordination mode, 3'-carboxylic group exhibits μ1-η1:η1 coordination mode, and 5'-position carboxylic group exhibits trans-syn-μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode, respectively. Due to the existence of chelate-monatomic bridge coordination mode, Eu-2 is built based on [Eu3(CO2)6] trinuclear cluster units, while Eu-1 is constructed from helical chains. We ameliorated the synthetic methodology, the pH value continues to improve to 4.9 and add K2C2O4 to the reaction system. Complexes 3-5 are heterometallic s/4f complexes, namely, the Ln3+ ion and the first main group K+ ion are cooperatively performed in the coordination process. Interestingly, Ln3+ ion and K+ ion are interconnected by carboxyl groups to afford two kinds of tetranuclear hetermetallic cluster, which are axial symmetry geometry. It is worth mentioning that, O5 and O13 bridging one lanthanide ion and two K+ ions adopt η3 coordination mode. This is significantly different from Eu-1 and Eu-2. The discovery of hetermetallic clusters help to expand hetermetallic clusters in Ln-MOFs system.

elements.content: In the IR spectra of complexes 1–5 (Figure S1, Supporting Information), the peaks at about 1600 and 1400 cm–1 are arising from asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of semirigid V-shaped ligand, respectively. This result is in line with that reported V-shaped ligand-based Ln analogues. For Eu-1, the band at 1700 cm–1 indicates that 5′-position carboxyl group is not incomplete deprotonated. The O–C–O vibration in plane occurs in the range of 580–800 cm–1 in middle intensity peaks. These phenomena are in line with the X-ray structural analysis. The results of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of extensive materials of 1–5 indicate that all major peaks are in well line with corresponding simulated PXRD pattern, indicating their high crystalline phase purity (). Due to the preferred crystal orientation of the samples, there are differences in intensity at the same peaks.

elements.content: To estimate the stability of the Ln–MOFs, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses in purified air are performed and the TG curves are listed in Figure S3. For Eu-1, the first weight loss is in the range of room temperature to 218 °C, which could be assigned to the removal of coordinated and free water molecules (found, 10.71%; calcd, 9.83%). Afterward, the whole framework of Eu-1 begins to collapse. The remaining product could be Eu2O3 (found, 32.59%; calcd, 32.04%). For Eu-2, the TG curve displays the first weight loss of 6.35 up to 160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.73%). The second weight loss of 50.54% (calcd 52.29%) from 400 to 530 °C corresponds to the decomposition of coordinated organic ligands. The remaining product could be Eu2O3 (found, 43.16%; calcd, 42.01%). Eu-3, Tb-4, and Gd-5 are isostructural and show similar TG curves. Hence, only Eu-3 is used to describe as a representative. For Eu-3, the first weight loss of 15.91% from 30 to 245 °C, which is close to the removal of coordinated and lattice water molecules (calcd 15.65%), and then the whole framework begins to collapse. The remaining weight is 36.26, 39.52, and 35.67% for Eu-3, Tb-4, and Gd-5, indicating that the final products are the mixture of Ln2O3 and K2O (calcd 35.27, 36.60, and 36.32%).

elements.content: Eu-1 crystallizes in the monoclinic with space group C2/c and exhibits a rare (5,5)-connected vbk 3D framework. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Eu3+ ions, one Hdcppa3– ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and one free water molecule (Figure S4a). Each Eu3+ ion is eight-coordinated in a distored bicapped trigonal prism geometry by six oxygen atoms (O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, and O7) from one Hdcppa3– ligand and O10 and O11 atoms from two water molecules (Figure S4b). The Eu–O distances vary from 2.315(4) to 2.564(4) Å, and the angles of O–Eu–O range from 51.01(12) to 156.21(16)° (Table S3 of Supporting Information), which all correspond to those reported for other Eu3+ complexes. Hdcppa3– ligand, which can be regarded as a pentadenta ligand, coordinates Eu3+ center in a μ5–η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode. Two phenyl rings of each H4dcppa ligand are noncoplanar and rotate away with dihedral angle of 71.39 (20)°. The oxygen atoms of O4 and O5 of 4-site carboxyl group from Hdcppa3– ligand bonding to the adjacent Eu3+ center to form an infinite 1D helix chains. Each of the double helixes consists of two interweaved right- and left-handed 21 helixes by sharing europium, carbon, and oxygen atoms, with screw-pitch of about 10.308 Å along the a axis (a). What’s more, the adjacent Eu3+ ions are connected through the O4 and O7 atoms deriving from one Hdcppa3– ligand, resulting in another infinite 1D zigzag chain along the c axis (b). Furthermore, two different 1D chains are linked by bridging O5 and O6 atoms, forming a 1D + 1D → 2D layer structure. (c and S5). Because of the longer distances between Eu3+ ions and O2 [Eu1–O2 = 2.533 (4) Å] and O3 [Eu1–O3 = 2.564 (4) Å] compared to other Eu–O bond distances, the 2D layer structures are connected by chelated O2 and O3 (d) to form an elegant 3D framework along the ab plane (e). Interestingly, the whole framework of Eu-1 is very like the “Chinese knots”, as shown in Figure S6. Omitting these guest molecules, the effective free volume is estimated using the PLATON software to be 330.3 Å3, about 9.9% of the unit volume of 3322.6 Å3.

Structural Description for Eu-1 

 Eu-1 crystallizes in the monoclinic with space group C2/c and exhibits a rare (5,5)-connected vbk 3D framework. The asymmetric unit consists of one independent Eu3+ ions, one Hdcppa3- ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and one free water molecule (Figure S4a). Each Eu3+ ion is eight-coordinated in a distored bicapped trigonal prism geometry by six oxygen atoms (O2, O3, O4, O5, O6, and O7) from one Hdcppa3- ligand and O10 and O11 atoms from two water molecules (Figure S4b). The Eu-O distances vary from 2.315(4) to 2.564(4) Å, and the angles of O-Eu-O range from 51.01(12) to 156.21(16)° (Table S3 of Supporting Information), which all correspond to those reported for other Eu3+ complexes. Hdcppa3- ligand, which can be regarded as a pentadenta ligand, coordinates Eu3+ center in a μ5-η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode. Two phenyl rings of each H4dcppa ligand are noncoplanar and rotate away with dihedral angle of 71.39 (20)°. The oxygen atoms of O4 and O5 of 4-site carboxyl group from Hdcppa3- ligand bonding to the adjacent Eu3+ center to form an infinite 1D helix chains. Each of the double helixes consists of two interweaved right- and left-handed 21 helixes by sharing europium, carbon, and oxygen atoms, with screw-pitch of about 10.308 Å along the a axis (a). What's more, the adjacent Eu3+ ions are connected through the O4 and O7 atoms deriving from one Hdcppa3- ligand, resulting in another infinite 1D zigzag chain along the c axis (b). Furthermore, two different 1D chains are linked by bridging O5 and O6 atoms, forming a 1D + 1D → 2D layer structure. (c and S5). Because of the longer distances between Eu3+ ions and O2 [Eu1-O2 = 2.533 (4) Å] and O3 [Eu1-O3 = 2.564 (4) Å] compared to other Eu-O bond distances, the 2D layer structures are connected by chelated O2 and O3 (d) to form an elegant 3D framework along the ab plane (e). Interestingly, the whole framework of Eu-1 is very like the "Chinese knots", as shown in Figure S6. Omitting these guest molecules, the effective free volume is estimated using the PLATON software to be 330.3 Å3, about 9.9% of the unit volume of 3322.6 Å3.

elements.content: Topological analysis is carried out to simplify and better understand the 3D framework. Regarding the structure of Eu-1, both the metal center and H4dcppa can be regarded as 5-connected nodes (Figure S7a). Thus, Eu-1 can be classified as a rare (5,5)-connected vbk net with a Schläfli symbol of (45·64·8) (45·64·8) (Figure S7b). Up to now, only a few examples of 5-connected networks have been documented.

elements.content: Eu-2 crystallizes in the monoclinic with space group C2/c and displays a novel 2D + 2D → 3D framework. The coordination environments of metal centers and coordination mode of H4dcppa ligand are described in Supporting Information (Figure S8). Comparing with Eu-1, the 5′-position carboxylic group is deprotonation when the pH value increased to 4.5 in H2O + DMF mixed solution, resulting to completely different coordination modes of Eu-2. The Eu-1 ion is linked to symmetry-related Eu-2 ions by six carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η2 and syn–trans-μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to afford a trinuclear [Eu3(CO2)6] paddlewheel with a Eu-1···Eu-2 distance of 3.9331 Å (a). Each trinuclear [Eu3(CO2)6], which serves as a SBU, is connected through four carboxylate groups (3′- and 5′-position) in μ1-η1:η1 and syn–trans-μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to furnish a double-stranded 1D chain along the a axis (b). The result leads to two neighboring SBUs staggered with each other. Each chain further linked to its adjacent neighbors by dcppa4– ligands (3- and 4-position) to generate the 2D layer structure (c and S9a), which are further connected by formic acid ligands to generated a 3D framework (e). With careful observation, we find the double-stranded 1D chains are linked together through a formic acid ligand to give another 2D layer structure (d and S9b), which situates in the 3D net. Thus, the superimposing of 2D + 2D → 3D structure of Eu-2 constitutes the final complicated framework. The final framework of Eu-2 is similarity to “dragon boats”, as shown in Figure S10. The total potential solvent volume is 2111.1 Å3, and the percentage of the effective free volume is 41.4%.

Structural Description for Eu-2 

 Eu-2 crystallizes in the monoclinic with space group C2/c and displays a novel 2D + 2D → 3D framework. The coordination environments of metal centers and coordination mode of H4dcppa ligand are described in Supporting Information (Figure S8). Comparing with Eu-1, the 5'-position carboxylic group is deprotonation when the pH value increased to 4.5 in H2O + DMF mixed solution, resulting to completely different coordination modes of Eu-2. The Eu-1 ion is linked to symmetry-related Eu-2 ions by six carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η2 and syn-trans-μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to afford a trinuclear [Eu3(CO2)6] paddlewheel with a Eu-1⋅⋅⋅Eu-2 distance of 3.9331 Å (a). Each trinuclear [Eu3(CO2)6], which serves as a SBU, is connected through four carboxylate groups (3'- and 5'-position) in μ1-η1:η1 and syn-trans-μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to furnish a double-stranded 1D chain along the a axis (b). The result leads to two neighboring SBUs staggered with each other. Each chain further linked to its adjacent neighbors by dcppa4- ligands (3- and 4-position) to generate the 2D layer structure (c and S9a), which are further connected by formic acid ligands to generated a 3D framework (e). With careful observation, we find the double-stranded 1D chains are linked together through a formic acid ligand to give another 2D layer structure (d and S9b), which situates in the 3D net. Thus, the superimposing of 2D + 2D → 3D structure of Eu-2 constitutes the final complicated framework. The final framework of Eu-2 is similarity to "dragon boats", as shown in Figure S10. The total potential solvent volume is 2111.1 Å3, and the percentage of the effective free volume is 41.4%.

elements.content: For simplifying and better understanding the intricate 3D framework with trinuclear SBUs, topological method was employed. As each dcppa4– connects with three trinuclear SBUs, the dcppa4– ligand can be treated as a 3–connected node, while the HCOOH ligand could be considered as a linear linker. In turn, the trinuclear SBU, connecting six dcppa4– ligands and two linear linkers, could be treated as an eight–connected node (Figure S11a). So the whole structure is simplified finally as (3,8)-connected net, which belongs to tfz-d type topology (Figure S11b).

As each dcppa4- connects with three trinuclear SBUs, the dcppa4- ligand can be treated as a 3-connected node, while the HCOOH ligand could be considered as a linear linker. In turn, the trinuclear SBU, connecting six dcppa4- ligands and two linear linkers, could be treated as an eight-connected node (Figure S11a). So the whole structure is simplified finally as (3,8)-connected net, which belongs to tfz-d type topology (Figure S11b).

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that complexes 3–5 are isostructural, crystallizing in the triclinic system with a space group of P1̅, featuring 3D open heterometallic s/4f framework. Herein, only the structure of Eu-3 is described representatively. The coordination environments of metal centers are described in Supporting Information (Figures S12a and S13). Notably, there are two crystallographically independent dcppa4– ligands in Eu-3, namely, type A (μ9-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η2:η1) and type B (μ8-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η1:η1; Figure S12b,c). It is worth mentioning that O5 and O13 bridging one Eu3+ ion and two K+ ions adopt the η3 coordination mode. As far as we know, it is the first time that this type of coordination mode is observed in Ln–K MOFs. Both type A and type B ligands are connected Eu3+ ions through carboxylate groups (3′- and 5′-position) in μ1-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to form a double-stranded 1D chain. Each chain further linked to its adjacent neighbors by dcppa4– ligands (3- and 4-position in a μ1-η1:η1 coordination mode) to generate the 2D layer structure (Figure S12d,e). The two 2D layer structures are similar to each other with a little difference coordination configurations of the carboxyl group of 5′-position (syn–syn−μ2-η1:η1 in type A and syn–trans−μ2-η1:η1 in type B). The two 2D layers are staggered with each other via Eu3+ center, resulting in a novel Eu–dcppa4– 2D + 2D → 3D structure (a). Moreover, the existence of a coordinated mode of dcppa4– and the K+ centers shows a particular type of K–dcppa4– 2D structure (b). Therefore, the finally 3D framework of Eu-3 is superposed by the Eu-dcppa4– 3D structure and K-dcppa4– 2D structure (c). There are 1D channels in the 3D framework with size of 16.64 × 8.36 Å along the c axis, while the K+ ions were located on the surfaces of the channels. The effective free volume of the framework is estimated to be 422.0 Å3, almost 20.1% per unit cell volume of 2100.3 Å3. The total potential solvent volumes of Tb-4 and Gd-5 are 427 and 400.5 Å3 (20.6 and 19.6% per unit cell volume), respectively.

Structural Description for {[Ln2K2(dcppa)2(H2O)6]⋅mH2O}n (Ln = Eu-3, Tb-4, Gd-5, m = 5 for Eu-3 and Tb-4; m = 4 for Gd-5)

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that complexes 3-5 are isostructural, crystallizing in the triclinic system with a space group of P1̅, featuring 3D open heterometallic s/4f framework. Herein, only the structure of Eu-3 is described representatively. The coordination environments of metal centers are described in Supporting Information (Figures S12a and S13). Notably, there are two crystallographically independent dcppa4- ligands in Eu-3, namely, type A (μ9-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η2:η1) and type B (μ8-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η1:η1; Figure S12b,c). It is worth mentioning that O5 and O13 bridging one Eu3+ ion and two K+ ions adopt the η3 coordination mode. As far as we know, it is the first time that this type of coordination mode is observed in Ln-K MOFs. Both type A and type B ligands are connected Eu3+ ions through carboxylate groups (3'- and 5'-position) in μ1-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to form a double-stranded 1D chain. Each chain further linked to its adjacent neighbors by dcppa4- ligands (3- and 4-position in a μ1-η1:η1 coordination mode) to generate the 2D layer structure (Figure S12d,e). The two 2D layer structures are similar to each other with a little difference coordination configurations of the carboxyl group of 5'-position (syn-syn-μ2-η1:η1 in type A and syn-trans-μ2-η1:η1 in type B). The two 2D layers are staggered with each other via Eu3+ center, resulting in a novel Eu-dcppa4- 2D + 2D → 3D structure (a). Moreover, the existence of a coordinated mode of dcppa4- and the K+ centers shows a particular type of K-dcppa4- 2D structure (b). Therefore, the finally 3D framework of Eu-3 is superposed by the Eu-dcppa4- 3D structure and K-dcppa4- 2D structure (c). There are 1D channels in the 3D framework with size of 16.64 × 8.36 Å along the c axis, while the K+ ions were located on the surfaces of the channels. The effective free volume of the framework is estimated to be 422.0 Å3, almost 20.1% per unit cell volume of 2100.3 Å3. The total potential solvent volumes of Tb-4 and Gd-5 are 427 and 400.5 Å3 (20.6 and 19.6% per unit cell volume), respectively.

elements.content: By carefully observing the whole framework of Eu-3, we found that two Eu-1 and Eu-2 metal centers and two K1 and K2 metal centers are connected by carboxyl groups forming two kinds of tetranuclear hetermetallic clusters, namely, [Eu2K2O8] and [Eu2K2O10] (d). Both of them exhibit axial symmetry geometry. Each tetranuclear clusters could be defined as an eight-connected node, while each dcppa4– ligands can be reduced to a 4-connected node. So the whole framework possesses a (4,4,8,8)-connected net, the corresponding Schläfli symbol is (46)2(46)2(412·612·84)­(412·612·84) (Figure S14). Moreover, the structural topology of Eu-3 has not been documented hitherto.

elements.content: In the structure of Eu-3, the 1D channels and open Lewis basic oxygen atoms active sites makes it interestingly, which means Eu-3 may become promising candidate as luminescent sensor. In this regard, Eu-3 was simply immersed in an ethanol solution of 0.001 mol/L MCl x (M = Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, respectively) for 2 h to form M n+–Eu-3 for luminescence studies. We have investigated the luminescence properties of M n+–Eu-3. The corresponding luminescence curve shows the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ ions (a) and only the highest emission peak at 614 nm were monitored under the perturbation of various cations, as depicted in . Most interestingly, the luminescence intensities of the M n+–Eu-3 are heavily relying on the identity of metal ions. On the one hand, alkali as well as alkaline–earth metal ions have an insignificant influence on the luminescent intensities. On the other hand, transition metal ions have varying degrees of quenching effect on the luminescent intensities. The significant luminescent quenching effect of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions are very clearly observed, indicative of the fact that Eu-3 can be considered as a promising luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions. Moreover, the pictures of M n+–Eu-3 (b) at room temperature showed the incorporation of Fe3+ or Cu2+ and rendered Eu-3 from bright to brown or blue. Additionally, under the excitation of 365 nm, M n+–Eu-3 exhibited the same red color with Eu-3, whereas Fe3+-incorporated or Cu2+-incorporated Eu-3 showed nonluminescent phenomenon. These results proved that Eu-3 could be luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions through luminescent quenching. This phenomenon can be obviously observed with the unaided eye.

Selectivity of Eu-3 luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions

In the structure of Eu-3, the 1D channels and open Lewis basic oxygen atoms active sites makes it interestingly, which means Eu-3 may become promising candidate as luminescent sensor. In this regard, Eu-3 was simply immersed in an ethanol solution of 0.001 mol/L MCl x  (M = Na+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Mn2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Pb2+, respectively) for 2 h to form M n+-Eu-3 for luminescence studies. We have investigated the luminescence properties of M n+-Eu-3. The corresponding luminescence curve shows the five characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+ ions (a) and only the highest emission peak at 614 nm were monitored under the perturbation of various cations, as depicted in . Most interestingly, the luminescence intensities of the M n+-Eu-3 are heavily relying on the identity of metal ions. On the one hand, alkali as well as alkaline-earth metal ions have an insignificant influence on the luminescent intensities. On the other hand, transition metal ions have varying degrees of quenching effect on the luminescent intensities. The significant luminescent quenching effect of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions are very clearly observed, indicative of the fact that Eu-3 can be considered as a promising luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions. Moreover, the pictures of M n+-Eu-3 (b) at room temperature showed the incorporation of Fe3+ or Cu2+ and rendered Eu-3 from bright to brown or blue. Additionally, under the excitation of 365 nm, M n+-Eu-3 exhibited the same red color with Eu-3, whereas Fe3+-incorporated or Cu2+-incorporated Eu-3 showed nonluminescent phenomenon. These results proved that Eu-3 could be luminescent sensor for Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions through luminescent quenching. This phenomenon can be obviously observed with the unaided eye.

elements.content: Furthermore, we investigated the influence of mixed cations on the luminescence intensity of Eu-3, 0.6 mL of Fe3+ (1 × 10–3 M) or Cu2+ (1 × 10–3 M) and 0.6 mL of ethanol solutions of other cations (1 × 10–3 M) were slowly dropped into a 4.8 mL suspension of Eu-3 in ethanol, respectively. The quenching effect of Fe3+ and Cu2+ on Eu-3 is not influenced by the introduced metal ions (Figures S15 and S16), suggesting that Eu-3 can selectively detect both Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions among the above 15 cations. Moreover, to explore the detection limit of Eu-3 as Fe3+ and Cu2+ probes, the different concentrations of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions in ethanol solutions were dropped into suspension of Eu-3 to form a series of suspensions of Fe3+–Eu-3 and Cu2+–Eu-3 in ethanol in the range of approximately 10–6–10–2 mol/L. The luminescence intensity of Eu-3 gradually decreases with increasing concentration of Fe3+ and Cu2+ (). The decrease of the luminescence intensity is still clearly observed when Eu-3 is immersed in 5 × 10–6 Fe3+ solution (10–6 mol/L Cu2+ solution), indicating that the detection limit of Eu–3 as a luminescent probe can reach 10–6 mol/L. As shown in the inset of , the luminescent intensity versus [Fe3+] and [Cu2+] plots can be curve-fitted into (I 0/I) = 2.05 + K SV[Fe3+] ((I 0/I) = 1.64 + K SV[Cu2+]), close to the Stern–Volmer equation: (I 0/I) = 1 + K SV[M], where I 0 is the luminescent intensity of Eu-3 in ethanol solution, while I is the luminescent intensity after metal ion incorporation; [M] represents the molar concentration of the metal ion; and K SV is the Stern–Volmer constant. The values of K SV are 4.3 × 104 L/mol for Fe3+ and 5.2 × 104 L/mol for Cu2+, demonstrating its obvious luminescent quenching on Eu-3.

elements.content: Many chemists have made great efforts on exploring the luminescence quenching mechanism. Though complexes 1–3 have permanent porosity, the existence of 1D channels and open Lewis basic oxygen active sites in the framework of Eu-3 provide an opportunity for sensing Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions. To confirm this sensing process, the luminescence intensity of Eu-3 at 614 nm (λex = 315 nm) was measured at different times in an ethanol solution. As shown in Figure S17, more than half of the luminescent intensity (53% for Fe3+ and 57% for Cu2+) of pure Eu-3 was decreased when Eu-3 was treated with Fe3+ and Cu2+ solution for 8 min. With more and more Fe3+ or Cu2+ diffused into the channels of Eu-3 or bonded to oxygen atoms, when the sensing time up to 2 h, the luminescent intensity of the sample decreases to 2.3% for Fe3+ and 1.9% for Cu2+, respectively. In the case that all apical oxygen atoms are coordinated, the luminescent intensity is mainly quenched when the sample is treated with Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions for 24 h. This sensing process is approved by the PXRD analyses. The PXRD patterns of the samples for 8 min to 24 h are almost identical with that of as-synthesized Eu-3 (Figure S18), demonstrating that the whole skeleton of the Eu-3 crystal does not change, although the luminescent intensity is largely quenched. A few new peaks appear in the PXRD pattern besides that of Eu-3 after 24 h. The result is indicative of a new structure form after a long time immersing, whereas the main skeleton of Eu-3 does not alter. In order to further check the results, the XPS studies of O 1s were performed on Eu-3 and M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The O 1s peak from free oxygen atoms at 531.97 eV in Eu-3 is shifted to 532.06 and 532.22 eV after the addition of Fe3+ and Cu2+, respectively (), indicating the weak bond between oxygen atoms and M n+ in M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The formation of weak bonds between oxygen atoms and Fe3+ or Cu2+ results in the change of the electron energy level of ligand, so that it is inefficient that the energy transfer occurs between ligand and Eu3+.

As shown in Figure S17, more than half of the luminescent intensity (53% for Fe3+ and 57% for Cu2+) of pure Eu-3 was decreased when Eu-3 was treated with Fe3+ and Cu2+ solution for 8 min. With more and more Fe3+ or Cu2+ diffused into the channels of Eu-3 or bonded to oxygen atoms, when the sensing time up to 2 h, the luminescent intensity of the sample decreases to 2.3% for Fe3+ and 1.9% for Cu2+, respectively. In the case that all apical oxygen atoms are coordinated, the luminescent intensity is mainly quenched when the sample is treated with Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions for 24 h. This sensing process is approved by the PXRD analyses. The PXRD patterns of the samples for 8 min to 24 h are almost identical with that of as-synthesized Eu-3 (Figure S18), demonstrating that the whole skeleton of the Eu-3 crystal does not change, although the luminescent intensity is largely quenched. A few new peaks appear in the PXRD pattern besides that of Eu-3 after 24 h. The result is indicative of a new structure form after a long time immersing, whereas the main skeleton of Eu-3 does not alter. In order to further check the results, the XPS studies of O 1s were performed on Eu-3 and M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The O 1s peak from free oxygen atoms at 531.97 eV in Eu-3 is shifted to 532.06 and 532.22 eV after the addition of Fe3+ and Cu2+, respectively (), indicating the weak bond between oxygen atoms and M n+ in M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The formation of weak bonds between oxygen atoms and Fe3+ or Cu2+ results in the change of the electron energy level of ligand, so that it is inefficient that the energy transfer occurs between ligand and Eu3+.

elements.content: Furthermore, the luminescence lifetime of Eu-3 in ethanol determines to be 664.52 μs; in contrast, Fe3+–Eu-3 and Cu2+–Eu-3 have decay times of 5.08 and 7.87 μs, respectively (Figure S19). It is indicated that the energy transfer from the ligand to Eu3+ ions is ineffective. Through the analysis of the above experimental results, we have speculated that the luminescence quenching process may be followed the two processes: (1) The Fe3+ or Cu2+ ions diffused into the channels of Eu-3 or attached to the surface of Eu-3 rapidly and encapsulated Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions are responsible for the quenching of the luminescence at a short period. Probably, the paramagnetic effect of Fe3+ and Cu2+ quench the luminescent properties. (2) As time progresses, Lewis basic sites on the pores may bond with Fe3+ or Cu2+ ions, and the interaction between Fe3+or Cu2+ and oxygen atoms changes the electron energy level of ligand resulted the inefficient energy transfer between ligand and Eu3+, leading to immediate photoluminescence quenching. The possible luminescence quenching mechanism of Eu-3 by Fe3+ and Cu2+ is shown in .

elements.content: The relevant electronic states of H4dcppa ligand have been investigated to study the energy transfer process in 1–4. It is well-known that Gd3+ complexes are the best choice for calculating the triplet energy levels of the organic ligand for the following two reasons: (1) The Gd3+ ion increases the intersystem crossing rate due to its heavy atom effect. (2) The Gd3+ ion’s first excited-state electronic level is at high energies (6P7/2 at around 32150 cm–1), there is no Gd3+ emission in the range of 200–800 nm. The observed luminescence is due to the ligand from complex. Therefore, the main energy transfer pathway is the radiative decay process. The triplet excited state (T1) of H4dcppa ligand (23364 cm–1, 428 nm τ = 1.44 ms) was estimated by the phosphorescence spectrum of Gd-5 at 77 K (Figure S20a). The singlet energy level (S1) of H4dcppa ligand is 29586 cm–1 (338 nm; Figure S20b). The intersystem crossing (ISC) process becomes effective when ΔE (S1–T1) > 5000 cm–1, which is raised by Reinhoudt. The ΔE (S1–T1) of H4dcppa (6222 cm–1) is above the threshold value indicating that the efficient ISC process. Generally, the mechanism of Eu3+ and Tb3+ luminescence has been explained by the four steps, as shown in . The process starts from (1) ligand-centered excitation from the singlet ground state (S0) to S1, (2) followed by ISC from S1 to T1, (3) energy transfer (ET) from T1 of the ligand to one or more of the Ln-centered 4fN excited states, (4) internal conversion from 5DJ state to the lowest quintet state and red/green emission via the f–f transitions. An ideal ligand to lanthanide metal energy transfer process needs ΔE(T1–5DJ) = 2500–4500 cm–1, which is raised by Latva. The T1 of H4dcppa is 4364 cm–1 higher than the 5D1 (5D1 = 19000 cm–1) level of Eu3+ and 2864 cm–1 higher than the 5D4 (5D4 = 20500 cm–1) level Tb3+ ions. In addition, there is no ligand-centered emission that appeared in 1–4, showing that the energy transfer process from T1 to 5DJ of Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions is efficient. What needs to be explained is that the nonradiative relaxation from 5D1 to the 5D0 level is efficient because of the absence of bands from 5D1 to ground state in Eu complexes.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of 1–4 were recorded on the crystalline samples both at 298 and 77 K and the luminescent data are summarized in Table S6. The strong, well-defined peaks in the spectra are typical for complexes containing trivalent Eu3+ ions and Tb3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties of the Complexes

Excitation and emission spectra of 1-4 were recorded on the crystalline samples both at 298 and 77 K and the luminescent data are summarized in Table S6. The strong, well-defined peaks in the spectra are typical for complexes containing trivalent Eu3+ ions and Tb3+ ions.

elements.content: The excitation spectra of 1–3 were obtained by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transition at 614 nm and displayed ligand-centered bonds in the range of 310–335 nm, which are attributed to the electronic transitions of H4dcppa ligand. Meanwhile, the faint f–f transitions 7F0 → 5D4 (360 nm), 7F0 → 5G2 (378 nm), 7F0 → 5L6 (394 nm), 7F0 → 5D3 (414 nm), 7F0 → 5D2 (464 nm), and 7F0 → 5D1 (534 nm) for the Eu3+ ion are observed. The enlarged excitation spectrum of Eu-1 is shown in Figure S21. The emission spectra for 1–3 were recorded under the excitation wavelength at 335, 310, and 320 nm. Maximum intensities situated at 579, 591, 614, 651, and 689 nm, respectively, were observed for the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) transitions, and two splitting peaks of the 5D0 → 7F4 transition happen at 689 and 700 nm in Eu-3 (a–c and S22a–c). The emission profile at 614 nm (5D0 → 7F2) is a very strong band, which determines the brilliant red luminescence of 1–3 (see the photographs of 1–3 under UV lamp). The 5D0 → 7F2 transition belonged to an electric dipole, is hypersensitive to the environment of Eu3+ ion, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is a magnetic dipole that is insensitive to the site symmetry. The intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1), about 9.57 for Eu-1, 5.89 for Eu-2, and 4.18 for Eu-3, documents that Eu3+ ions with low symmetry in 1–3 occupy sites and have no inversion center, which is coincident with the structure analyses of 1–3.

elements.content: The lifetime values for the 5D0 level, monitored with the more intense line of 5D0 → 7F2 transition, were recorded at 298 and 77 K (). The observed luminescent decay curves fitted to the single exponential functions I = I 0 + A exp­(−t/τ). summarized the relevant values of the complexes. The luminescence lifetimes in the solid state are determine to be 311.55, 698.36, and 519.61 μs at 298 K. At 77K, luminescence lifetimes values are 341.73 μs for Eu-1, 791.77 μs for Eu-2, and 576.78 μs for Eu-3, which are higher than those of 298 K. Thereby, the conclusion reflects the existence of thermally activated deactivation processes. It is well-known that the O–H oscillators in close proximity to Eu3+ ion center could quenches the luminescence effectively by vibration relaxations. The observed lifetime for Eu-2 is the longest among the three Eu complexes because of the least water molecules in the crystal structure. In Eu-3, the luminescence lifetime, due to the potassium-to-europium charge transfer (MMCT), is longer than Eu-1, which with less water molecules. Thus, these three complexes show the increasing luminescence lifetimes in the order Eu-2 > Eu-3 > Eu-1 both at 298 and 77 K, which is consistent with the crystal structural models.
elements.clean_text: The lifetime values for the 5D0 level, monitored with the more intense line of 5D0 → 7F2 transition, were recorded at 298 and 77 K (). The observed luminescent decay curves fitted to the single exponential functions I = I 0 + A exp(-t/τ).  summarized the relevant values of the complexes. The luminescence lifetimes in the solid state are determine to be 311.55, 698.36, and 519.61 μs at 298 K. At 77K, luminescence lifetimes values are 341.73 μs for Eu-1, 791.77 μs for Eu-2, and 576.78 μs for Eu-3, which are higher than those of 298 K. Thereby, the conclusion reflects the existence of thermally activated deactivation processes. It is well-known that the O-H oscillators in close proximity to Eu3+ ion center could quenches the luminescence effectively by vibration relaxations. The observed lifetime for Eu-2 is the longest among the three Eu complexes because of the least water molecules in the crystal structure. In Eu-3, the luminescence lifetime, due to the potassium-to-europium charge transfer (MMCT), is longer than Eu-1, which with less water molecules. Thus, these three complexes show the increasing luminescence lifetimes in the order Eu-2 > Eu-3 > Eu-1 both at 298 and 77 K, which is consistent with the crystal structural models.

Absolute quantum yield.

The excitation spectrum of Tb-4 shows ligand centered band at 320 nm. Upon excitation at 320 nm, a series of bands at 489, 545, 586, 621, 652, and 683 nm, corresponding to the characteristic transitions of Tb3+ ion: 5D4 → 7F J (J = 6, 5, 4, 3, 2). The 5D4 → 7F5 (545 nm) emission is the strongest which determined brilliant green luminescence of Tb-4 (d). As shown in Figure S22d, the respective emission peaks are split and narrowed at 77 K. The luminescent lifetime is determined to be 1201.04 μs at 298 K monitored at more intense 5D4 → 7F5 emission. The 5D4 lifetime value of Tb-4 indicate that it is temperature-dependent because of τRAD (1275.10 μs) decreasing by ∼6%, while the temperature goes down from 298 to 77 K. Accordingly, the thermally activated deactivation process is absence.

elements.content: summarized the ΦLn and Φsen data of 1–4. It is clear from that the change trendency of quantum yields is similar to luminescence lifetimes. Tb-4 exhibits higher quantum yields as well as luminescence lifetimes than that of Eu complexes 1–3 because the f–f transitions from 5D4 to 7F J are parity- and spin-forbidden transitions. Moreover, the energy gap between the luminescent excited state and ground state manifolds of Eu3+ and Tb3+ are approximately 12000 and 14800 cm–1, respectively. Around about the third proximate O–H oscillators (νOH = 3300–3500 cm–1) vibrational overtone, efficient Eu3+ excited states coupling occurs, while the fourth as for Tb3+, this will be the powerful explanation of the less efficient quenching observed for Tb3+, of which the Franck–Condon overlap factor is less favorable.

elements.content: In conclusion, five 3D novel Ln–MOFs of diverse structural topologies have been prepared by hydro­(solvo)­thermal method through tuning reaction pH values, potassium source, base, and solvent. The results illustrate that the H4dcppa ligand can take various coordination modes and configurations to construct fascinating frameworks: a rare 3D (5,5)-connected vbk network of Eu-1; 2D + 2D → 3D network based on trinuclear paddlewheel [Eu3(CO2)6] SBUs of Eu-2; heterometallic Ln–K 3D (4,4,8,8)-connected (46)2(46)2(412·612·84)­(412·612·84) topological network with 1D Lewis basic oxygen atoms site–decorated open channel of 3–5. Our results show that Eu–3 are highly selective and sensitive to the Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions by luminescence quenching. The luminescence quenching caused by Fe3+ and Cu2+ may be ascribed to weak binding of oxygen atoms to M n+ in M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The luminescence lifetimes as well as Φoverall show that the H4dcppa can sensitize the luminescence of Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions effectively in complexes 1–4. Therefore, our research work not only enriches the crystal structure of Ln–MOFs, but also expands the field of luminescent sensor materials, and further investigation on this theme is currently underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, five 3D novel Ln-MOFs of diverse structural topologies have been prepared by hydro(solvo)thermal method through tuning reaction pH values, potassium source, base, and solvent. The results illustrate that the H4dcppa ligand can take various coordination modes and configurations to construct fascinating frameworks: a rare 3D (5,5)-connected vbk network of Eu-1; 2D + 2D → 3D network based on trinuclear paddlewheel [Eu3(CO2)6] SBUs of Eu-2; heterometallic Ln-K 3D (4,4,8,8)-connected (46)2(46)2(412⋅612⋅84)(412⋅612⋅84) topological network with 1D Lewis basic oxygen atoms site-decorated open channel of 3-5. Our results show that Eu-3 are highly selective and sensitive to the Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions by luminescence quenching. The luminescence quenching caused by Fe3+ and Cu2+ may be ascribed to weak binding of oxygen atoms to M n+ in M n+-incorporated (M n+ = Fe3+ or Cu2+). The luminescence lifetimes as well as Φoverall show that the H4dcppa can sensitize the luminescence of Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions effectively in complexes 1-4. Therefore, our research work not only enriches the crystal structure of Ln-MOFs, but also expands the field of luminescent sensor materials, and further investigation on this theme is currently underway.

A mixture of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (44.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4dcppa (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (6 mL). The final pH value was adjusted to 4.0 using 0.5 mol·L–1 potassium hydrate. After stirring for half–hour in air, the mixture was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, which was heated to 160 °C for 5 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient condition. Colorless block-shaped crystals of Eu-1 were collected, yield: 31.8 mg, 58% based on H4dcppa. Elemental analysis calcd for [C16H13EuO12 (549.22)]: C, 34.99, H, 2.39%; found: C, 34.93, H, 2.37%. A mixture of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (44.6 g, 0.1 mmol) and H4dcppa (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) in distilled water (4 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; 2 mL). The pH value of the mixture was increased to 4.5 by using 0.5 mol·L–1 potassium hydrate. The mixture was stirred at ambient condition for 20 min. After that the mixture was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The reactor was heated to 160 °C for 4 days and cooled to ambient temperature naturally. Finally, colorless block-shaped crystals of Eu-2 were collected with 47% (29.5 mg) yield based on H4dcppa. Elem. anal. calcd for [C16.5H10Eu1.5O12 (628.19)]: C, 31.55, H, 1.60%; found: C, 31.51, H, 1.59%. A mixture of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (44.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), H4dcppa (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and K2C2O4 (18.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in distilled water (6 mL). A total of 0.5 mol·L–1 potassium hydrate was added to adjust pH value of reaction system to 4.9. The mixture was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel after stirring for a half-hour in air. The reactor was heated to 160 °C for 5 days, and cooled to ambient temperature naturally. Colorless block-shaped crystals of Eu-3 were collected with 51% yield (64.5 mg) based on H4dcppa. cln_elements.content:
To estimate the stability of the Ln–MOFs, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses in purified air are performed and the TG curves are listed in Figure S3. For Eu-1, the first weight loss is in the range of room temperature to 218 °C, which could be assigned to the removal of coordinated and free water molecules (found, 10.71%; calcd, 9.83%). Afterward, the whole framework of Eu-1 begins to collapse. The remaining product could be Eu2O3 (found, 32.59%; calcd, 32.04%). For Eu-2, the TG curve displays the first weight loss of 6.35 up to 160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.73%). The second weight loss of 50.54% (calcd 52.29%) from 400 to 530 °C corresponds to the decomposition of coordinated organic ligands. The remaining product could be Eu2O3 (found, 43.16%; calcd, 42.01%). Eu-3, Tb-4, and Gd-5 are isostructural and show similar TG curves. Hence, only Eu-3 is used to describe as a representative. For Eu-3, the first weight loss of 15.91% from 30 to 245 °C, which is close to the removal of coordinated and lattice water molecules (calcd 15.65%), and then the whole framework begins to collapse. The remaining weight is 36.26, 39.52, and 35.67% for Eu-3, Tb-4, and Gd-5, indicating that the final products are the mixture of Ln2O3 and K2O (calcd 35.27, 36.60, and 36.32%).

Structural Description for {[Ln<sub>2</sub>K<sub>2</sub>(dcppa)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]·<italic>m</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>n</sub> (Ln = <bold>Eu-3</bold>, <bold>Tb-4</bold>, <bold>Gd-5</bold>, <italic>m</italic> = 5 for <bold>Eu-3</bold> and <bold>Tb-4</bold>; <italic>m</italic> = 4 for <bold>Gd-5</bold>)

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that complexes 3–5 are isostructural, crystallizing in the triclinic system with a space group of P1̅, featuring 3D open heterometallic s/4f framework. Herein, only the structure of Eu-3 is described representatively. The coordination environments of metal centers are described in Supporting Information (Figures S12a and S13). Notably, there are two crystallographically independent dcppa4– ligands in Eu-3, namely, type A (μ9-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η2:η1) and type B (μ8-η2:η2:η1:η3:η1:η2:η1:η1; Figure S12b,c). It is worth mentioning that O5 and O13 bridging one Eu3+ ion and two K+ ions adopt the η3 coordination mode. As far as we know, it is the first time that this type of coordination mode is observed in Ln–K MOFs. Both type A and type B ligands are connected Eu3+ ions through carboxylate groups (3′- and 5′-position) in μ1-η1:η1 and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes to form a double-stranded 1D chain. Each chain further linked to its adjacent neighbors by dcppa4– ligands (3- and 4-position in a μ1-η1:η1 coordination mode) to generate the 2D layer structure (Figure S12d,e). The two 2D layer structures are similar to each other with a little difference coordination configurations of the carboxyl group of 5′-position (syn–syn−μ2-η1:η1 in type A and syn–trans−μ2-η1:η1 in type B). The two 2D layers are staggered with each other via Eu3+ center, resulting in a novel Eu–dcppa4– 2D + 2D → 3D structure (a). Moreover, the existence of a coordinated mode of dcppa4– and the K+ centers shows a particular type of K–dcppa4– 2D structure (b). Therefore, the finally 3D framework of Eu-3 is superposed by the Eu-dcppa4– 3D structure and K-dcppa4– 2D structure (c). There are 1D channels in the 3D framework with size of 16.64 × 8.36 Å along the c axis, while the K+ ions were located on the surfaces of the channels. The effective free volume of the framework is estimated to be 422.0 Å3, almost 20.1% per unit cell volume of 2100.3 Å3. The total potential solvent volumes of Tb-4 and Gd-5 are 427 and 400.5 Å3 (20.6 and 19.6% per unit cell volume), respectively.
